attributes.title: Prejudice Reduction, Ethnic Violence, and Internal Migration in Karachi, Pakistan

q1.value: Prejudice Reduction, Ethnic Violence, and Internal Migration in Karachi, Pakistan

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We will be carrying out a survey in June-July 2018, weeks prior to national elections, in the megacity of Karachi, Pakistan. In this pre-analysis plan, we outline the design, hypotheses, and planned analysis for two survey experiments embedded into the survey. The survey is designed to address two distinct research questions, each with a separate survey experiment. Research Question 1: Ethnic identities are often activated during times of political competition. During election campaigns, politicians engage in rhetoric emphasizing the real or alleged crimes of ethnic outgroups, such as their involvement in violence, and seek to highlight the extent to which their own group is under attack. Because violence is thought to "harden" the boundaries between ethnic groups, engaging in such rhetoric is an ideal political tool for ethnic entrepreneurs and political elites who are able to present themselves as the necessary protectors of the ethnic in-group. In these contexts, what kind of messaging can help to reduce intergroup prejudice? In particular, can framing ethnic violence as being primarily perpetrated by politicians and criminals for purposes of personal gain dampen prejudicial attitudes towards ordinary members of outgroups? Can such a frame counter the negative effects of electoral campaigning on the basis of ethnic groups being under attack by rival groups? Research Question 2: Anti-migrant hostility and nativist violence is not uncommon in contexts where internal migration is frequent. We measure attitudes toward internal migrants in the city of Karachi and aim to test the impact of a brief pro-migrant appeal on such attitudes. Specifically, can reframing internal migration as having contributed positively to the city of Karachi--increasing migrants' claim to ownership over the city--increase tolerant attitudes towards these migrants?

q16.value: Survey Experiment 1 will test the impact of two different framings of urban violence on inter-ethnic relations. Survey Experiment 2 will test the impact of a pro-internal migrant message on attitudes toward internal migrants. The full pre-analysis plan provides further detail on specific hypotheses and also lists planned analyses for the detection of heterogenous treatment effects.

q17.value: Subjects will be randomly assigned to each experimental group (including a placebo for each experiment, which will serve as the control group). Hypotheses will be tested by looking at how the pre-specified outcomes differ across experimental groups, including through simple difference-in-means tests, ANOVA, Wilcoxon rank sum tests for ordinal outcomes, and OLS models with covariates.

attributes.title: Morality, Authority, and Empathy: How to Elicit Altruism toward the Internally Displaced

q1.value: Morality, Authority, and Empathy: How to Elicit Altruism toward the Internally Displaced

q2.value: Han Il Chang | Leonid Peisakhin | Peter Van der Windt

q5.value: We thank RISD in Congo, and specifically Jean Paul Zibika, Emmanuel Kandate and Antoine Ciza, for their comments on this design.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The number of internally displaced persons (IDPs) – individuals who have been forcibly displaced within their country’s borders due to conflict – surpasses 60 million. IDPs are often unable to return for long periods to their settlements of origin, and many never return. It is also well established that IDPs ordinarily face major difficulties integrating into new host communities and often suffer from physical privations and mental disorders as a result of forced displacement. A potentially powerful way to improve the IDPs’ situation is to engender more altruistic behaviors and attitudes toward the IDPs. In this project we explore the effectiveness of three different appeals (to morality, authority, or perspective taking) in improving altruism towards internally displaced persons, and we ask whether these effects vary depending on whether the IDP is a co-ethnic or not.

q16.value: H1: An appeal to morality will improve altruism towards IDPs H2: An appeal to authority will improve altruism towards IDPs H3: An appeal to perspective taking will improve altruism towards IDPs H4: Villagers will be more altruistic towards IDPs of the same ethnicity. H5: Villagers will be more altruistic towards IDPs when they believe that material benefits may accrue in the future from being altruistic in the present.

q17.value: Short and longer run measures based on survey data (conducted shortly after treatment) and additional, original behavioral measures collected about two weeks after treatment and during a six-month period after treatment.

attributes.title: Citizen Support for Government Surveillance: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Kuwait

q1.value: Citizen Support for Government Surveillance: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Kuwait

q2.value: Nadiya Kostyuk | Yuree Noh | Tarek Masoud

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: There have been extensive revelations about government surveillance of ordinary citizens in the name of national security, even in the democratic United States. It is generally considered that people value their privacy. As privacy rights have become a key issue around the world, there has been a surge of studies examining the state's use of surveillance to monitor their citizens. Yet, we know little about how much security outweighs privacy to the masses: under which conditions are citizens willing to relinquish their privacy to the government? In a survey experiment fielded in Kuwait, we demonstrate how exposure to different types of online threats and their targets affect public's risk perception and their support for government surveillance. Contrary to conventional wisdom, we expect citizens not to give up their privacy rights for the sake of national security. Instead, we hypothesize that individuals are more likely to accept government violation of their privacy when this is framed as necessary to protect citizens against threats to themselves (i.e. personal versus national) than when it is framed as necessary to protect the political order (national). Despite a low probability of terrorist acts, we expect citizens to be willing to sacrifice their privacy in the terrorism (versus cyber crime) condition due to devastating and physically evident consequences of these acts.

q16.value: This project argues that the effect of different types of threats and targets will produce divergent risk perceptions, resulting in divergent public support for surveillance. Using a 2 x 2 design, we directly manipulate a cyber threat's two key characteristics --- its type (criminal versus terrorist) and target (personal versus national) --- while keeping other threat's characteristics constant. We expect that risk perceptions of cyber threats that target participants directly (i.e criminal condition) will be relatively low, despite an increasingly growing evidence that such threats may present more risk to individual than other security threats, such as terrorism. Additionally, we hypothesize that individuals are more likely to accept government violation of their privacy when this is framed as necessary to protect citizens against threats to themselves (i.e. personal versus national) than when it is framed as necessary to protect the political order (national). Individual's cognitive biases might explain such a perception. We include five categories of dependent variables: support for government surveillance, value of privacy, support for government spending on cyber capabilities, personal online behavior, and risk assessment.

q17.value: In our experimental design embedded in a survey fielded in Kuwait, we manipulate two variables of threats: type and target. This design allows us to systematically examine how the citizen responses vary in different plausible contexts. Subjects will be randomly assigned to one of four manipulation conditions or a control. The enumerators will read a corresponding short text. Control: More than 90% of Kuwaitis today have one or more social media accounts Treatment 1 (criminal / personal): More than 90% of Kuwaitis today have one or more social media accounts. Criminals have increasingly targeted Kuwaitis on social media to steal their private information. Treatment 2 (terrorist / personal): More than 90% of Kuwaitis today have one or more social media accounts. Terrorists have increasingly targeted Kuwaitis on social media to steal their private information. Treatment 3 (criminal / national): More than 90% of Kuwaitis today have one or more social media accounts. Criminals have increasingly targeted government entities in Kuwait on social media to steal their secret information. Treatment 4 (terrorist / national): More than 90% of Kuwaitis today have one or more social media accounts. Terrorists have increasingly targeted government entities in Kuwait on social media to steal their secret information.

attributes.title: The Impact of Russian Election Meddling on Allies’ Trust in the United States

q1.value: The Impact of Russian Election Meddling on Allies’ Trust in the United States

q5.value: I gratefully acknowledges support from the School of Politics & International Relations, ANU, and the Australian Research Council (Future Fellowship: FT140100763)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The identity of the United States as a democracy is claimed to be a core part of its so-called “soft power” (Nye 2001). If the United States were not perceived as a democracy, or as a diminished or partial democracy, would this affect its ability to maintain its global alliance network? Would it affect its ability to pursue other important foreign policy goals? In the context of the unusual presidency of Donald Trump, and the now well-documented attempts by Russia to interfere in the 2016 United States election that brought him to power, scholars have focused on Americans’ reactions to foreign election meddling (Tomz & Weeks 2018) and on the impact of Trump on America’s image abroad (Agadjanian & Horiuchi 2018). However, another potentially important aspect of these seemingly new phenomena in international politics is the impact on the U.S. image as a democracy in foreign countries, perhaps most significantly in formal U.S. military allies. U.S. image as a democracy, for example captured in the phrase “leader of the free world,” has been central to its international role since the end of the Second World War. Most of the United States’ key military alliances involve other democracies, including almost all NATO states, Japan, Australia, and South Korea. It is a reasonable assumption that perception of the U.S. as a democracy is both an important justification for the existence and purpose of those alliances, and crucial for their maintenance and survival. But what would happen if citizens of allied countries came to see U.S. democracy as severely flawed, or even came to regard it as non-democratic? In recent (non-public) testimony to the U.S. Congress, former F.B.I. lawyer Lisa Page made the following statement regarding the purpose of Russian election interference (Goldman, Schmidt & Fandos 2019): “In the Russian Federation and in President Putin himself, you have an individual whose aim is to disrupt the Western alliance and whose aim is to make Western democracy more fractious in order to weaken our ability, America’s ability and the West’s ability to spread our democratic ideals.... That’s the goal, to make us less of a moral authority....” In addition to the ability to “spread democratic ideals,” another crucial role for U.S. “moral authority” as a democracy, I contend, might be the maintenance of its military alliance system. This aspect of foreign election meddling has not, to the best of our knowledge, been investigated in the social science literature. I run a study assessing the impact of information about the attempt (and success) of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election on the views of Australians and Britons about the United States as a military ally. The online survey experiment has a total of 3,000 respondents (in the UK or Australia) randomly assigned to one of three groups. After some initial questions, one group will be asked to read a text (Treatment 1) about Russian interference in U.S. elections that claims the election results were affected and U.S. democracy was “reduced.” Another group will be asked to read a text (Treatment 2) about Russian interference in U.S. elections that claims the election results were not affected and U.S. democracy was “not reduced.” A third group will read no text and just move on to the next section of the survey (Control). To understand the impact of (successful) election interference in U.S. democracy and the potential perception of U.S. weakness due to the fact of election interference (regardless of its success), I take the following strategies. First, I word the treatments in such a way that the characterization of the potency of the election interference is similar in each treatment, while the reasons for failure in Treatment 2 are portrayed as outside of U.S. control (“most forms of political persuasion seem to have little effect at all”). Second, I examine three pairs of hypotheses, discussed in the following sections, relating to different aspects of respondents’ attitudes towards the alliance. I theorize that “trust” (H1a & H1b) and “shared values” (H2a & H2b) are closely related to the identity of the U.S. as a democracy, but not to its capabilities, while more general or realpolitik aspects of attitudes towards alliances (H3a & H3b) are related to both democracy and capability. Thus, if Treatment 2 conveys a perception of weaker U.S. capabilities, this treatment effect should emerge more strongly in H3b than in H1b or H2b, which I explain below.

q16.value: H1a: Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will be associated with lower trust in the U.S. as an ally. H1b: Receiving information about Russian election meddling will not be associated with lower trust in the U.S. as an ally. H2a: Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will be associated with lower belief in shared values with the U.S. as an ally. H2b: Receiving information about Russian election meddling will not be associated with lower belief in shared values with the U.S. as an ally. H3a: Receiving information about the reduction of US democracy will be associated with lower support for alliance with the U.S. H3b: Receiving information about Russian election meddling will be associated with lower support for alliance with the U.S. H4: Treatment effects expected across our first three sets of hypotheses (H1a, H2a, H3a&b) will be attenuated for respondents who have high favorability for President Donald Trump. H5: Treatment effects expected across our first three sets of hypotheses (H1a, H2a, H3a&b) will be attenuated for respondents who have low trust in the mass media.

q17.value: Hypotheses 1a and 1b: Trust in the US as an ally More specifically, I theorize that providing respondents with information about Russian election meddling in the US and its effectiveness can reduce trust in the U.S. to fulfil its alliance obligations. Because the motivation for the alliance relationship is based on common interests shared by democracies, the logic goes, once this fundamental aspect of U.S. identity is reduced, citizens of allied democracies will also reduce their expectations that the U.S. will have an interest in defending other democracies. This expectation is reflected in our first hypothesis (H1a): Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will be associated with lower trust in the U.S. as an ally. This main hypothesis will be tested with a Treatment 1, which presents a text of information compiled from U.S. news media that asserts that Russian election interference occurred, that it was successful in manipulating the election result, and that the U.S. has not responded effectively to prevent this from happening again. The treatment includes the title “Election Interference Has Reduced American Democracy” and also the statement “Experts now say the U.S. can no longer be considered a ‘fully functioning democracy.’” The outcome variable to test the main hypothesis is the item “If the UK’s (Australia’s) security were threatened by some other country, how much trust do you feel the UK (Australia) could have in the United States to come to the UK’s (Australia’s) defence?” Trust is perhaps the central dynamic of a military alliance, since each party must trust the other to honor the agreement. However, I also recognize that providing information about Russian election interference in the U.S. might convey an impression of U.S. weakness in terms of basic capabilities and the resolve to address foreign threats. If the U.S. cannot protect one of its core domestic institutions from interference by a known and less-powerful adversary, its desirability as an ally on purely pragmatic terms might be questioned. But this effect should not relate to trust. Rather, it relates to effectiveness. I therefore include a second group that is provided with Treatment 2, which again presents a text of information compiled from U.S. news media that asserts that Russian election interference occurred, but that it was not successful in manipulating the election result. The treatment includes the title “Election Interference Has Not Reduced American Democracy” and also the statement “Experts say the U.S. can still longer be considered a ‘fully functioning democracy.’” This treatment thus conveys that while the election interference might not have succeeded, it nevertheless was serious and did occur, which paints a similar picture of U.S. weakness while maintaining its democratic character. I expect that the U.S. will still be trusted as a democratic ally, even if its effectiveness may be doubted, by respondents receiving Treatment 2. This expectation is reflected in our second hypothesis (H1b): Receiving information about Russian election meddling will not be associated with lower trust in the US as an ally. I again use the outcome variable focused on trust in the U.S. to test this hypothesis. Hypotheses 2a and 2b: Belief in shared values with the US as an ally Another way in which beliefs about U.S. democracy may be related to attitudes towards the U.S. alliance is shared values. Citizens may believe that common values among societies strengthen the reliability and desirability of a military alliance. In the case of the U.S. and its democratic allies, U.S. identity as a democracy should be one major source of such common values. A sense of shared values may be important for attitudes towards the alliance because these will be reflected in common interests, but it may also be important because shared values imply a moral motivation to defend an ally. The hypothesis to be tested regarding values is H2a: Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will be associated with lower belief in shared values with the US as an ally. The treatment for this is also Treatment 1, and the survey item used to measure the outcome is: “Here are some different arguments about the United Kingdom’s (Australia’s) alliance relationship with the United States. For each one, please indicate how much you personally agree or disagree. The British (Australians) and Americans share many common values and ideals. A strong alliance is a natural extension of this.” I expect that respondents who receive information about reduced American democracy will believe there are lower shared values with the UK (Australia), and will therefore be less likely to agree with the statement. Again, I want to compare the treatment effect of reduced democracy due to election meddling with that of election meddling that did not reduce democracy. I use Treatment 2 to assess this, based on our fourth hypothesis (H2b): Receiving information about Russian election meddling will not be associated with lower belief in shared values with the U.S. as an ally. Hypotheses 3a and 3b: Support for alliance with the US While I have specific expectations for attitudes towards the U.S. alliance involving trust and shared values based on a distinction between perceived democracy and perceived weakness, more general attitudes of support for the alliance might not be subject to such nuances. Both U.S. democracy and U.S. strength might contribute to general support for the alliance among citizens in allied countries, since both of these are desirable qualities for an ally of a democracy. I therefore expect that both Treatment 1 and Treatment 2 will have negative effects on attitudes towards the alliance in general. These expectations are reflected in hypotheses H3a: Receiving information about the reduction of US democracy will be associated with lower support for alliance with the U.S.; and H3b: Receiving information about Russian election meddling will be associated with lower support for alliance with the U.S. These will be tested on five additional questions (listed in the pre-analyis plan) about the alliance having to do with concepts of “attack”, “interests” “China and Russia” “decline” and “choice”. If most of these items elicit the expected treatment effect, I will take this as support for a strong general negative effect on attitudes towards the alliance. I will use these questions separately as well as a composite measure build based on them. Hypotheses 4 and 5: Moderation effects I expect attitudes towards President Trump and towards the news media to condition the treatment responses. Specifically, I expect the following two moderation effects: H4: Treatment effects expected across our first three sets of hypotheses (H1a, H2a, H3a&b) will be attenuated for respondents who have high favorability for President Donald Trump. H5: Treatment effects expected across our first three sets of hypotheses (H1a, H2a, H3a&b) will be attenuated for respondents who have low trust in the mass media.

q24.value: Australian National University Human Research Ethics Committee Protocol 2019/539.

registration_responses.q17: Hypotheses 1a and 1b: Trust in the US as an ally More specifically, I theorize that providing respondents with information about Russian election meddling in the US and its effectiveness can reduce trust in the U.S. to fulfil its alliance obligations. Because the motivation for the alliance relationship is based on common interests shared by democracies, the logic goes, once this fundamental aspect of U.S. identity is reduced, citizens of allied democracies will also reduce their expectations that the U.S. will have an interest in defending other democracies. This expectation is reflected in our first hypothesis (H1a): Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will be associated with lower trust in the U.S. as an ally. This main hypothesis will be tested with a Treatment 1, which presents a text of information compiled from U.S. news media that asserts that Russian election interference occurred, that it was successful in manipulating the election result, and that the U.S. has not responded effectively to prevent this from happening again. The treatment includes the title “Election Interference Has Reduced American Democracy” and also the statement “Experts now say the U.S. can no longer be considered a ‘fully functioning democracy.’” The outcome variable to test the main hypothesis is the item “If the UK’s (Australia’s) security were threatened by some other country, how much trust do you feel the UK (Australia) could have in the United States to come to the UK’s (Australia’s) defence?” Trust is perhaps the central dynamic of a military alliance, since each party must trust the other to honor the agreement. However, I also recognize that providing information about Russian election interference in the U.S. might convey an impression of U.S. weakness in terms of basic capabilities and the resolve to address foreign threats. If the U.S. cannot protect one of its core domestic institutions from interference by a known and less-powerful adversary, its desirability as an ally on purely pragmatic terms might be questioned. But this effect should not relate to trust. Rather, it relates to effectiveness. I therefore include a second group that is provided with Treatment 2, which again presents a text of information compiled from U.S. news media that asserts that Russian election interference occurred, but that it was not successful in manipulating the election result. The treatment includes the title “Election Interference Has Not Reduced American Democracy” and also the statement “Experts say the U.S. can still longer be considered a ‘fully functioning democracy.’” This treatment thus conveys that while the election interference might not have succeeded, it nevertheless was serious and did occur, which paints a similar picture of U.S. weakness while maintaining its democratic character. I expect that the U.S. will still be trusted as a democratic ally, even if its effectiveness may be doubted, by respondents receiving Treatment 2. This expectation is reflected in our second hypothesis (H1b): Receiving information about Russian election meddling will not be associated with lower trust in the US as an ally. I again use the outcome variable focused on trust in the U.S. to test this hypothesis. Hypotheses 2a and 2b: Belief in shared values with the US as an ally Another way in which beliefs about U.S. democracy may be related to attitudes towards the U.S. alliance is shared values. Citizens may believe that common values among societies strengthen the reliability and desirability of a military alliance. In the case of the U.S. and its democratic allies, U.S. identity as a democracy should be one major source of such common values. A sense of shared values may be important for attitudes towards the alliance because these will be reflected in common interests, but it may also be important because shared values imply a moral motivation to defend an ally. The hypothesis to be tested regarding values is H2a: Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will be associated with lower belief in shared values with the US as an ally. The treatment for this is also Treatment 1, and the survey item used to measure the outcome is: “Here are some different arguments about the United Kingdom’s (Australia’s) alliance relationship with the United States. For each one, please indicate how much you personally agree or disagree. The British (Australians) and Americans share many common values and ideals. A strong alliance is a natural extension of this.” I expect that respondents who receive information about reduced American democracy will believe there are lower shared values with the UK (Australia), and will therefore be less likely to agree with the statement. Again, I want to compare the treatment effect of reduced democracy due to election meddling with that of election meddling that did not reduce democracy. I use Treatment 2 to assess this, based on our fourth hypothesis (H2b): Receiving information about Russian election meddling will not be associated with lower belief in shared values with the U.S. as an ally. Hypotheses 3a and 3b: Support for alliance with the US While I have specific expectations for attitudes towards the U.S. alliance involving trust and shared values based on a distinction between perceived democracy and perceived weakness, more general attitudes of support for the alliance might not be subject to such nuances. Both U.S. democracy and U.S. strength might contribute to general support for the alliance among citizens in allied countries, since both of these are desirable qualities for an ally of a democracy. I therefore expect that both Treatment 1 and Treatment 2 will have negative effects on attitudes towards the alliance in general. These expectations are reflected in hypotheses H3a: Receiving information about the reduction of US democracy will be associated with lower support for alliance with the U.S.; and H3b: Receiving information about Russian election meddling will be associated with lower support for alliance with the U.S. These will be tested on five additional questions (listed in the pre-analyis plan) about the alliance having to do with concepts of “attack”, “interests” “China and Russia” “decline” and “choice”. If most of these items elicit the expected treatment effect, I will take this as support for a strong general negative effect on attitudes towards the alliance. I will use these questions separately as well as a composite measure build based on them. Hypotheses 4 and 5: Moderation effects I expect attitudes towards President Trump and towards the news media to condition the treatment responses. Specifically, I expect the following two moderation effects: H4: Treatment effects expected across our first three sets of hypotheses (H1a, H2a, H3a&b) will be attenuated for respondents who have high favorability for President Donald Trump. H5: Treatment effects expected across our first three sets of hypotheses (H1a, H2a, H3a&b) will be attenuated for respondents who have low trust in the mass media.
registration_responses.q24: Australian National University Human Research Ethics Committee Protocol 2019/539.

attributes.title: Sources of Misperception: Media Choice and the Economic Impact of Legal Immigration

q1.value: Sources of Misperception: Media Choice and the Economic Impact of Legal Immigration

q2.value: Patrick W. Kraft | Nicholas R. Davis | Taraleigh Davis | Amanda J. Heideman | Jason T. Neumeyer | Shin Young Park

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Various important issues at the center of today's politics---such as immigration or climate change---are imbued with citizens' misperceptions. A growing body of research therefore explores whether such misperceptions can be mitigated by providing corrective information. While such corrections have been shown to reduce factual misperceptions, they appear to have little to no effect on underlying attitudes. Our study contributes to this active research area by examining how variations in the source and delivery mode of corrective information moderate their effectiveness. In our experimental design, respondents are exposed to a news article about immigration reported by either Fox News or MSNBC. The main treatment consists of either allowing free choice of the respective media source or assigning it randomly. Our outcomes of interest focus on the perceived economic impact of legal immigration, attitudes towards immigrants, and engagement with the news article. In order to isolate the effect of delivery mode and messenger, the news content is held constant across news sources.

q16.value: Our study explores how the way people access corrective information influences the likelihood of its success in reducing misperceptions. In general, we expect that those who were able to choose a news agency are more likely to pick a source similar to their usual media diet. Additionally, we expect those who read a news story from a trusted news source (and who are able to pick the news agency) are more inclined to evaluate the article positively and change their attitudes in the direction of the news article. See pre-analysis plan for more detailed information.

q17.value: To test our hypotheses, we will rely on simple differences-in-means and OLS estimators. See pre-analysis plan for more detailed information.

attributes.title: Who supports mano dura? A candidate conjoint experiment in Morelia, Mexico

q1.value: Who supports mano dura? A candidate conjoint experiment in Morelia, Mexico

q2.value: Lauren Young | Thomas Zeitzoff | Hannah Baron

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Candidates and parties who support harsh criminal justice policies popularly known as mano dura are frequently elected in countries with high perceived and actual levels of crime. Examples include ARENA in El Salvador, Hernandez in Honduras, and Bolsonaro in Brasil. In addition, a range of recent winning candidates (Rodrigo Duterte and Jair Bolsonaro, for example) are known for taking actions or making statements that overtly support extrajudicial justice. Do voters support these candidates specifically because of those policies, or are they elected because of other traits? What characteristics do people who support mano dura and pro-vigilante candidates have? To assess this question empirically, we will carry out a candidate conjoint experiment in a community affected by high levels of crime: the city of Morelia in the Mexican state of Michoacán. Morelia is a city of approximately 600,000 people and has documented elevated rates of homicides, car theft, and home robbery. This conjoint experiment will be carried out in two waves of a panel survey around a separate experiment in which people participate in community discussions about how crime is handled.

q16.value: If mano dura and pro-vigilante policies themselves are popular and contribute to getting candidates elected: H1A: The average voter in our sample will be more likely to vote for a candidate who proposes to let the police torture accused criminals H2A: The average voter in our sample will evaluate more positively the security policy of a candidate who proposes to let the police torture accused criminals H3A: The average voter in our sample will be more likely to vote for a candidate who proposes to let citizens punish criminals H4A: The average voter in our sample will evaluate more positively the security policy of a candidate who proposes to let citizens punish criminals If mano dura and pro-vigilante policies are not popular (meaning that candidates are getting elected in spite of instead of because of them): H1B: The average voter in our sample will be less likely to vote for a candidate who proposes to let the police torture accused criminals H2B: The average voter in our sample will evaluate less positively the security policy of a candidate who proposes to let the police torture accused criminals H3B: The average voter in our sample will be less likely to vote for a candidate who proposes to let citizens punish criminals H4B: The average voter in our sample will evaluate less positively the security policy of a candidate who proposes to let citizens punish criminals

q17.value: We will use linear regression to calculate the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE) of all of the candidate characteristics. We will cluster standard errors by participant. We will include a base set of control variables in all regressions, including treatment assignment in our related experiment and the characteristics of the alternative candidate.

q19.value: 750-900 respondents, each asked about 2 different candidate matches in 2 separate waves of a panel survey

q27.value: a survey firm called Buendia y Laredo

attributes.title: The Psychology of Self-Defense and Self-Determination

q1.value: The Psychology of Self-Defense and Self-Determination

q2.value: Austin Horng-En Wang | Yao-Yuan Yeh | Fang-Yu Chen | Charles Kuan-Sheng Wu

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In the 2016 Taiwan National Security Survey (TNSS hereafter) conducted by Duke University and National Chengchi University, 60.4% of Taiwanese respondents believed that “the majority of Taiwanese people will fight against China if China invaded Taiwan.” Meanwhile, only 27.1% of the respondents said that he/she would join the fight by him/herself. Since the military power of the People’s Republic of China keeps rising, the survey reflects emerging problems for Taiwanese people. First of all, why is the number of Taiwanese people willing to fight so low? Why is there a considerable gap between Taiwanese people’s determination and the belief of others? Second, if we can figure out the factors driving the level of self-determination and self-defense, under what condition could Taiwan government possibly enhance them?

q16.value: Project 1 aims at examining the Prisoners’ Dilemma model on the psychology of self-defense. I would like to test two treatments (1) increasing future orientation (decreasing temporal discounting) and (2) Changing the perception that others will fight. H1: People who are treated to be more patient are much likely to fight against invasion H2: People who perceived that others will fight are much likely to fight against invasion H3: People who are more patient and perceived others will fight are much likely to fight Project 2 aims at examining how the US foreign policy and the attribution among Taiwanese will influence Taiwanese people’s willingness to defend themselves. I would like to test two treatments (1) whether US will help Taiwan once Taiwan was invaded by China and (2) whether the China’s invasion is owing to Taiwan independence or not. H1: Taiwanese people are much willing to defend themselves if China’s invasion during the status quo (rather than after Taiwan declared independence). H2: Taiwanese people are much willing to defend themselves if US will protect Taiwan. H3: Taiwanese people are the most willing to defend themselves if US will protect Taiwan and China invades during the status quo. H4: Taiwanese people are the least willing to defend themselves if US will not protect Taiwan and China invades after Taiwan declared independence.

q17.value: In Project 1, Q10 and Q11 are designed for testing H1~H3. Since it is a random assignment, comparing mean will be used for testing the hypothesis. Logit regression will also be used for controlling the covariates. In Project 2, Q24 is designed for testing H1~H4. Since it is a random assignment, comparing mean will be used for testing the hypothesis. Ordinal regression will also be used for controlling the covariates.

attributes.title: Nudging towards healthier food choice for children using cognitive dissonance: a lab-in-field experiment

q1.value: Nudging towards healthier food choice for children using cognitive dissonance: a lab-in-field experiment

q2.value: Trang Mai Nguyen | Marrit van den Berg | Alan de Brauw

q5.value: We thank Minh Nguyen and Oanh Tran (Mekong Development Research Institute) and Henry Abbink (Wageningen University and Research) for their support in data collection. The study is funded by the CGIAR A4NH Research Programme.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Poor food choice can lead to several detrimental health consequences, including increased risks of NCDs, which are on the rise in LMICs (Kelly, 2016; Popkin, 2003). A recent study found that 42 percent of children in Vietnam’s urban areas are overweight and/or obese, compared to 35 percent in rural areas. The same study also stated Vietnamese students tend to pursue unhealthy food habits, consuming sugary drinks and sweet food products. How to steer children’s choice towards healthier options is an important question for schools and families. Nudges are a potentially powerful and increasingly trusted public policy tool to improve people’s behavior, including eating more healthy (Bauer & Reisch, 2019; Sunstein, Reisch, & Kaiser, 2018). While multiple behavioral science concepts have been tested and scaled up, the study of cognitive dissonance related to eating/food attitudes and behaviors in the food and nutrition domain has been under-developed, particularly in influencing healthy food behaviors (Ong, Frewer, & Chan, 2017). Cognitive dissonance relates to the internal discomfort people feel when their beliefs, emotions, attitudes and actions enter into contradiction with one another. People are then motivated to reduce this tension by adjusting their beliefs or actions. Empirical evidence has shown the effectiveness of arousing cognitive dissonance in changing behaviours towards desirable ends such as water use reduction (Dickerson et al., 1992), sustained weight loss (Axsom and Cooper, 1985), condom use (Stone et al., 1994), and reducing hypothetical bias in contingent valuation studies (Alfnes et al., 2010). Our study contributes by (1) running one of the first experiments, to our knowledge, on children’s food choice using a dissonance arousal nudge; (2) evaluating whether the dissonance arousal nudge can improve the use of information provision nudge; and (3) joining the nascent body of experimental work on children’s food choice, especially in LMICs.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: The provision of information decreases the likelihood of children choosing full sugar milk. Hypothesis 2: Inducing “hypocrisy” increases the likelihood of selecting healthier food choice due to cognitive dissonance. Hypothesis 3: When there is a delay between the intervention and the target behavior, children are more likely to select sweetened milk in both treatment groups, compared to the no-delay condition. Hypothesis 4: When there is a delay between the intervention and the target behavior, children are equally likely to select sweetened milk in the treatment 2 compared to treatment 1.

q17.value: We run a lab-in-field experiment on primary school children in Dong Anh district, Hanoi. The 4th and 5th grade classes will be randomly assigned to one of the following: Control: the students will watch a placebo video (e.g. an educational video about traffic safety). Treatment 1: the students will watch a (animated, educational) video about cutting down sugar in their diet. The video talk about the consequences of eating excessive sugar and include examples on how to cut down on added sugar: e.g. drinking plain milk instead of flavored/sweetened milk; choosing bubble milk tea with less sugar. The video is short (about 1 – 1.5 minute long), with key messages and cute animation. Treatment 2: the same video as treatment 1 + dissonance arousal treatment (using “hypocrisy paradigm”) The dissonance arousal treatment follows 2 step procedure: The children are first asked to record a message containing the key content of the video to share with other students “publicly make statements consistent with some normative standards”. They are also told that the recording they prepare with their names will be sent to children in other schools to promote healthy eating. In a second step aimed at inducing dissonance, a brief set of simple questions will be asked to link to the actual past behavior of respondents. We also divide the schools into 2 groups: In the first 6 schools, the children will make the food choice immediately after being treated. In the later 6 schools, the children will be occupied with another task (answering the endline questionnaire) after being treated and before making the food choice. The children will be offered three choices of milk as outcome measurement.

q19.value: ~136 classrooms x 10 children, in total around 1,360 children

q27.value: Mekong Development Research Institute, Hanoi, Vietnam. Contact: minhnguyen@mdri.org.vn

registration_responses.q5: We thank Minh Nguyen and Oanh Tran (Mekong Development Research Institute) and Henry Abbink (Wageningen University and Research) for their support in data collection. The study is funded by the CGIAR A4NH Research Programme.

attributes.title: How Parties Reduce Citizens’ Political Trust

q1.value: How Parties Reduce Citizens’ Political Trust

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Studies show that citizens who have lost trust in the political institution are prone to cast an anti-establishment vote for populist parties. Yet, we know very little about how or whether parties can erode levels of political trust among citizens. This experiment sets out to examine how party cues are able to shape citizens’ political trust, and whether radical right parties’ rhetoric may dampen not only voters’ political trust but also democratic legitimacy.

q16.value: H1: Party cues containing distrust in political institutions decrease trust among partisans, especially among AfD supporters H2: (Dis)trust cues should also affect levels of democratic legitimacy among partisans H3: (Dis)trust cues should increase acceptance of illegal behavior. H4: Respondents’ subjective social status moderates the effects of H1-H3.

q17.value: We develop and conduct a survey experiment with a nationally representative sample of citizens in Germany. Survey participants are recruited by the online survey company. The survey is conducted in German. Below we provide the experiment treatment and the survey questions.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Can cues from in-group elites change mass attitudes on immigration?

q16.value: Exposure to messages on immigration from in-group elites will cause a variety of immigration-related attitudes to change in respondents who share their partisanship.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: Can cues from in-group elites change mass attitudes on immigration?
registration_responses.q16: Exposure to messages on immigration from in-group elites will cause a variety of immigration-related attitudes to change in respondents who share their partisanship.
